Hi,

I suggest the following problems familly, described in
  "Truss topolo=
gy optimization with discrete design variables - Guaranteed global optimali=
ty and benchmark examples"
  http://www.topopt.dtu.dk/?q=3Dnode/727

Some n=
ice features:
   - Global optimums are known, you trully knows if your appr=
oach is doing well or not
   - Interesting number of variables to optimize,=
 can go close to 1000. Actually, you can push it as much as you want, if yo=
u have CPU time to burn.
   - Fitness evaluation is rather fast and not too=
 hard to code (a very sparse linear system to build and then to solve with =
conjugate gradient, with opportunities of a lot of optimization)


Cheers,
=
Alex

--- En date de=C2=A0: Ven 19.11.10, Jan van der Lugt <janlugt@gmail.c=
om> a =C3=A9crit=C2=A0:

De: Jan van der Lugt <janlugt@...>
Objet: [n=
eat] Hard problems for HyperNEAT
=C3=80: neat@yahoogroups.com
Date: Vendred=
i 19 novembre 2010, 12h31







=C2=A0



  


    
      
      
      He=
llo everyone,

We are working on tuning the 30-something parameters for Hyp=
erNEAT (2.6 in our case) and we are looking for hard problems that do not t=
ake too much computational effort, which means a run can take about 15 minu=
tes. We already tried most of the problems supplied with HyperNEAT, but mos=
t of them proved to be either too simple (near-optimal fitness within a few=
 generations) or too expensive to run (one run can take hours). In this con=
text a run is a complete run of HyperNEAT with n generations, not the evalu=
ation of 1 generation. We cut back on the number of generations (default is=
 300), so problems that take 30-45 minutes for a whole run are also ok.


O=
ur interest lies only in using our tool to tune the parameters, so we won't=
 use the source code of the experiments for anything other than parameter t=
uning and we will hand our results (e.g. parameters and best performance) b=
ack to you in exchange for letting us use your work (provided we got to tun=
ing your problem). As a result of this work, we hope to be able to release =
validated tuning software for use with HyperNEAT.

Regards,
Jan van der Lug=
t
